title: Raising Concerns
description: Explore how you bring up issues and concerns with your partner.

questions.text: When something bothers me, I tend to...
choices: Bring it up fairly quickly
Wait to see if it keeps bothering me
Hint at it and hope they notice
Keep it to myself unless it's really big

therapeutic.rationale: Issue-raising patterns affect relationship health. Quick-raisers address early; waiters filter for importance; hinters hope for mind-reading; keepers suppress. Gottman research shows gentle startup prevents escalation.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The quick-raiser may overwhelm the keeper; the keeper may explode after too much buildup. Find a sustainable pattern for raising issues.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared raising patterns create predictability about how issues surface.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you typically raise concerns? Does it work well for you?

questions.text: The difference between a complaint and criticism is something I...
choices: Understand and try to complain rather than criticize
Sometimes blur when I'm upset
Haven't thought much about
Find challenging to navigate in the moment

therapeutic.rationale: Complaint vs. criticism awareness is crucial. Complaints address behavior ('I felt hurt when...'); criticism attacks character ('You always...'). This distinction predicts relationship success. Awareness helps but applying it when upset is hard.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different awareness levels are fine—this is learnable. The key is being open to feedback about how your concerns land.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared awareness helps you both raise issues constructively.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you tend toward complaints or criticisms? How do you think your partner experiences how you raise issues?

questions.text: When I need to raise a difficult topic, I prefer to...
choices: Find a calm moment and bring it up gently
Just say it—I'm direct
Write it down first to organize my thoughts
Wait for the right time, which sometimes never comes

therapeutic.rationale: Difficult topic approaches vary. Calm-moment seekers set the stage; direct types dive in; writers organize; waiters delay. All can work, but indefinite waiting creates buildup and resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different approaches can complement. The direct type can learn timing from the calm-moment seeker; the waiter can learn from the direct type that issues don't resolve themselves.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared approach creates aligned expectations about how hard topics surface.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you approach difficult conversations? What would make them easier?

questions.text: When I raise a concern, I hope my partner will...
choices: Listen and try to understand my perspective
Not get defensive or take it personally
Work with me to find a solution
Acknowledge my feelings are valid

therapeutic.rationale: Desired responses to concerns shape satisfaction. Listen-hopers want understanding; non-defensive hopers want openness; solution-seekers want action; validation-seekers want acknowledgment. All are reasonable needs.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these responses are valuable—they can all happen. Share which matters most so your partner knows where to start.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared hopes for response create aligned expectations about what good receiving looks like.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What response do you most want when you raise a concern? Are you getting it?

questions.text: Something that makes it hard for me to raise issues is...
choices: Fear of my partner's reaction
Worry about hurting them
Not knowing how to say it well
Past experiences where it didn't go well

therapeutic.rationale: Barriers to raising issues prevent healthy communication. Fear of reaction creates walking on eggshells; worry about hurting leads to suppression; skill gaps are solvable; past wounds need healing. Naming barriers helps address them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different barriers need different solutions. Fear of reaction may signal safety issues; skill gaps are teachable; past wounds may need repair.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared barriers create mutual understanding about why issues go unaddressed.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes it hard for you to raise concerns? What would help?
